subject: RE: [junit] Running tests in some specified sequence

messageBody:
Hi Francois,

You are right, this is one way of doing this.

However, I prefer not to put this logic in a build file.

Usally, the ant build file I use just contains this:

...
<batchtest fork="yes">
<fileset dir="${classes.dir}">
<include name="com/something/**/Test*.class"/>
</fileset>
</batchtest>
...

If I start to put all kinds of exceptions at this single place, things will
get messy very quickly.

Regards,

tt

> One thing you might want to try is to use Ant to run your unit tests.
> In Ant, you would use different batch tests to test the lower level
> parts, the the next higher part, etc. etc.
>
> Hope that helps !
> Francois
>
> Taras Tielkes wrote:
> > Hi,
> >
> > I have a layered API class model that I'd like to unit test.
> >
> > The API is layered in the sense that some high level APIs
> depend on lower
> > level APIs. Other higher level APIs are built on the high
> level APIs.
> >
> > I have written unit tests for each of these APIs.
> >
> > These unit tests can be run in any sequence, however: I'd
> like to specify
> > that the unit tests for the lower level APIs should be run first.
> > When these tests pass, the higher level APIs can be tested,
> having some
> > confidence that the lower level works.
> >
> > The reason is that when an error occurs in a low level API,
> it's easier to
> > diagnose when it occurs in the unit test for the lower
> level API, rather
> > than as a result of the higher level API calling the low level API.
> >
> > When I add tests to a TestSuite using one of the addXXX()
> methods, is the
> > sequence of adding the tests the same sequence if which the
> tests are run?
> >
> > If not, how can specify that a subset of all tests 'should'
> be run in some
> > sequence? (Note: not *must*, the unit tests can still be
> run in *any*
> > sequence, but I'd like the stuff that tests the low level
> parts of the code
> > to run first)
> >
> > If TestSuite does not respect the sequence of the addXXX()
> calls for the
> > running of the tests, can I implements this by extending TestSuite?
> >
> > Thanks in advance for any comments on this! (I'm pretty new
> to unit testing
> > in general)
> >
> > tt
